recipe.name: Burton Ale

hop.name: Goldings, East Kent
hop.notes:
Used For: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales
Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor
Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings
Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

hop.name: Northern Brewer
hop.notes:
Also called Hallertauer Northern Brewers
Use for: Bittering and finishing both ales and lagers of all kinds
Aroma: Fine, dry, clean bittering hop.  Unique flavor.
Substitute: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Hallertauer
Examples: Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar,

hop.name: Fuggles
hop.notes:
Used For: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers
Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma
Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette
Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

hop.name: Fuggles
hop.notes:
Used For: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers
Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma
Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette
Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

fermentable.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) UK
fermentable.notes:
Base malt for all English beer styles
Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt

fermentable.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
fermentable.notes:
Adds body, color and improves head retention.
Also called "Crystal" malt.

fermentable.name: Brown Sugar, Light
fermentable.notes: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

misc.name: Irish Moss
misc.notes: Fining agent that aids in the post-boil protein break.  Reduces protein chill haze and improves beer clarity.

misc.name: Polyclar
misc.notes: Plastic powder that reduces chill haze by removing tannins and proteins.  Add to secondary after yeast has settled.  Amounts vary by manufacturer -- check instructions before adding. Do not boil.

yeast.name: Burton Ale
yeast.notes: Burton-on-trent yeast produces a complex character.  Flavors include apple, pear, and clover honey.
yeast.bestFor: All English styles including Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout and Bitters.

water.name: Burton On Trent, UK
water.notes:
Distinctive pale ales strongly hopped.  Very hard water accentuates the hops flavor.
Example: Bass Ale

style.name: English Pale Ale
style.notes: Famous style from Burton-on-Trent.  Stronger body than ordinary bitter, but slightly less bitter.  A balanced, easy drinking beer that is malty and strong but not overbearing.
style.profile: Medium to full body, with medium to high bitterness and hop aroma.  Dry with a defined hop flavor.  Golden to copper color.  Crystal malt evident.  Low carbonation for kegs, medium for bottled version.
style.ingredients: English malt.  Crystal malt.  English hops.  Water with high Calcium Sulfate (gypsum) profile enhances bitterness perception (i.e. famous Burton-on-Trent Water)
style.examples: Bass Pale Ale, Whitbread Pale Ale, Royal Oak

equipment.name: Brew Pot  (6+gal) and Igloo/Gott Cooler (5 Gal)
equipment.notes: Popular all grain setup.  5 Gallon Gott or Igloo cooler as mash tun with false bottom, and 7-9 gallon brewpot capable of boiling at least 6 gallons of wort.  Primarily used for single infusion mashes.

mashStep.name: Mash In
mashStep.description: Add 11.25 qt of water at 170.5 F

mashStep.name: Mash Out
mashStep.description: Add 7.20 qt of water at 185.9 F

recipe.tasteNotes: A smooth tasting pale ale -- full in body and a great long lasting head.  Another great beer to stock -- favorite with guests.  Make's a great black and tan when combined with light bodied Irish stout.

recipe.name: Dry Stout

hop.name: Goldings, East Kent
hop.notes:
Used For: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales
Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor
Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings
Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

fermentable.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) UK
fermentable.notes:
Base malt for all English beer styles
Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt

fermentable.name: Barley, Flaked
fermentable.notes: Adds significant body to Porters and Stouts.  High haze producing protein prevents use in light beers.

fermentable.name: Black Barley (Stout)
fermentable.notes:
Unmalted barley roasted at high temperature to create a dry, coffee like flavor.
Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts.
Gives "dryness" to a stout or porter -- much more so than regular Roasted Barley

misc.name: Irish Moss
misc.notes: Fining agent that aids in the post-boil protein break.  Reduces protein chill haze and improves beer clarity.

misc.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
misc.notes: Reduces PH of water for mashing and sparging.   Alters water profile -- used to harden soft water.  Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

yeast.name: Irish Ale
yeast.notes: Dry diacetyl, fruity flavor characteristic of stouts.  Full bodied, dry, clean flavor.
yeast.bestFor: Irish Dry Stouts, Porter, Scottish Ale, Brown Ale, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine

water.name: Dublin, Ireland
water.notes: Irish ale water - used for dark, malty strong ales with medium bitterness.  Famous for dry stouts.

style.name: Dry Stout (Irish)
style.notes: Famous Irish Stout (AKA Guiness). Dry roasted almost coffee like flavor.  Irish versions have low starting gravity.  Often mixed with soured, pasturized beer to give a slight acidity as well.
style.profile: Full body perception from Flaked Barley, thought starting gravity may be low.  Dry roasted flavor.  Generous hops, though malt flavor will dominate. Complex fruity flavor. Black opaque color.
style.ingredients: English malt. Roasted Barley and Flaked Barley for all grain.  Some chocolate or black patent used in extract recipes. Goldings or Fuggles hops.  Low sulfate, high calcium water.

equipment.name: Brew Pot  (6+gal) and Igloo/Gott Cooler (5 Gal)
equipment.notes: Popular all grain setup.  5 Gallon Gott or Igloo cooler as mash tun with false bottom, and 7-9 gallon brewpot capable of boiling at least 6 gallons of wort.  Primarily used for single infusion mashes.

mashStep.name: Mash In
mashStep.description: Add 10.00 qt of water at 165.9 F

mashStep.name: Mash Out
mashStep.description: Add 6.40 qt of water at 193.1 F

recipe.notes: A very simple all grain beer that produces a great Guiness-style taste every time.  So light in body that I have even made black and tans with it using a full body pale ale in the bottom of the glass.
recipe.tasteNotes: One of my favorite stock beers - I always keep a keg on hand.  Rich flavored dry Irish Stout that is very simple to make.  Perfect every time!

recipe.name: Porter

hop.name: Fuggles
hop.notes:
Used For: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers
Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma
Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette
Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

fermentable.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) Bel
fermentable.notes:
Base malt for all beer styles
Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts

fermentable.name: Black (Patent) Malt
fermentable.notes:
Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters
Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.

fermentable.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 10L
fermentable.notes:
Adds body, color and improves head retention.
Also called "Crystal" malt.

fermentable.name: Chocolate Malt
fermentable.notes:
Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor.
Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts
Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

fermentable.name: Munich Malt - 10L
fermentable.notes:
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer.
Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention.
Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

misc.name: Irish Moss
misc.notes: Fining agent that aids in the post-boil protein break.  Reduces protein chill haze and improves beer clarity.

misc.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
misc.notes: Reduces PH of water for mashing and sparging.   Alters water profile -- used to harden soft water.  Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

yeast.name: English Ale
yeast.notes: Classic ESB strain best for English style milds, bitters, porters and English style stouts.  Leaves a clear beer with some residual sweetness.
yeast.bestFor: English Pale Ale, ESB, India Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Porter, Sweet Stouts and Strong Ales

style.name: Robust Porter
style.notes: Stronger, darker version of porter with a slight dryness.  Flavor derived from chocolate and black malts, but lacks the strong roasted flavor of a dry stout.
style.profile: Medium to full body, slightly dry. Well balanced, low to medium malt flavor and hop bitterness.  Dark brown to black color. Medium to no hop flavor.  Low ester, fruitiness, diacytl.  Low to med carbonation.
style.ingredients: English malt. Dark Crystal, chocolate and black or roast malt. Traditional english ale hops and yeast.  Moderate carbonate water.

equipment.name: Brew Pot  (6+gal) and Igloo/Gott Cooler (5 Gal)
equipment.notes: Popular all grain setup.  5 Gallon Gott or Igloo cooler as mash tun with false bottom, and 7-9 gallon brewpot capable of boiling at least 6 gallons of wort.  Primarily used for single infusion mashes.

mashStep.name: Mash In
mashStep.description: Add 13.75 qt of water at 165.9 F

mashStep.name: Mash Out
mashStep.description: Add 8.80 qt of water at 193.1 F

recipe.tasteNotes: Smooth tasting complex English porter.  A bit on the "robust" side.

recipe.name: Wit

hop.name: Goldings, East Kent
hop.notes:
Used For: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales
Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor
Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings
Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

fermentable.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) Bel
fermentable.notes:
Base malt for all beer styles
Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts

fermentable.name: Wheat, Flaked
fermentable.notes:
Flaked wheat adds to increased body and foam retention
Used in place of raw or torrified wheat for faster conversion and better yield.
May be used in small amounts to improve head retention and body
Examples: Belgian White beer, Wit

misc.name: Coriander Seed
misc.notes: Used in Belgian Wit, Whites, and Holiday ales.  Very good when used in light wheat ales.  Often used with Bitter Orange Peel.

misc.name: Orange Peel, Bitter
misc.notes: Made from the Curaco Orange Peel, peels are green-gray in color.  Used to add a distinctive flavor to Belgian Wits and White beers.

yeast.name: Belgian Wit Ale
yeast.notes: Phenolic and tart.  The original yeast used to produce Wit in Belgium.

style.name: Witbier
style.notes: Distinctive Wit or "White" beer spiced with bitter Curacao orange peel and coriander. A distinctive yeast strain provides orange aroma/flavor.
style.profile: Light to medium body. Unmalted wheat adds body and disctinctive flavor. Large white head. Low hop bitterness and flavor. Pale yellow color. Moderate carbonation.  Some chill haze is OK.
style.ingredients: Belgian pale malt. Up to 50% unmalted wheat (torrified or flaked often used). 5-10% flaked or rolled oats. Noble hops (Hallertauer or Saaz). Wit yeast. Curaco bitter orange peel and coriander. Soft water.

equipment.name: Brew Pot  (6+gal) and Igloo/Gott Cooler (5 Gal)
equipment.notes: Popular all grain setup.  5 Gallon Gott or Igloo cooler as mash tun with false bottom, and 7-9 gallon brewpot capable of boiling at least 6 gallons of wort.  Primarily used for single infusion mashes.

mash.name: Single Infusion, Medium Body
mash.notes: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

mashStep.name: Mash In
mashStep.description: Add 11.25 qt of water at 165.9 F

mashStep.name: Mash Out
mashStep.description: Add 6.30 qt of water at 196.6 F

recipe.notes: Many thanks to Jay Russ for starting me on Wit - and providing some starter recipes from which this one eventually evolved!
recipe.tasteNotes: Great tasting Wit!  A summer favorite! Lacy white head that lasts and lasts. Distinctive, light wheat beer with a hint of spice.
